awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Engineering Research Center for Resilient Rural Infrastructure (RRI)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Planning Grants for Engineering Research Centers competition was run as a pilot solicitation within the ERC program.  Planning grants are not required as part of the full ERC competition, but intended to build capacity among teams to plan for convergent, center-scale engineering research.

Rural areas in the U.S. are home to sixty million people, occupy 97% of the land area, and supply the bulk of the nation's food and natural resources. The overarching goal of the proposed activity is to understand and positively impact the significant physical and human infrastructure needs of rural U.S. communities through research supporting the design, development, and implementation of resilient rural infrastructure.  One of the challenges in conducting large-scale research is to simultaneously ensure significant potential impact while keeping the studies tractable so as to not overwhelm resources. In this planning grant, various types of rural communities will be targeted such as: communities in the southeast U.S., Puerto Rico, and Native American communities within the Great Plains. These communities and the educational institutions that support them will be targeted in order to increase the participation of groups and geographic regions that are too often underrepresented in STEM disciplines.

The primary objective of this project is to leverage the resources of a planning grant to develop and nurture relationships with the stakeholder community in a deliberate, early-stage process in an effort to develop a research team that is well poised to successfully compete for an Engineering Research Center addressing a highly complex, high-societal impact challenge. Inadequate and failing rural infrastructure is an important though arguably overlooked problem of national significance requiring center-scale, converging engineering research. If successful, this will be the nation's first-ever center dedicated primarily to the study and improvement of rural infrastructure. The goal is to develop a convergent research team of multidisciplinary subject-matter experts to successfully reengineer the nation's rural infrastructure. However, the current team is lacking stakeholders from the target rural communities and the educational institutions that support them (largely primary and secondary schools and local junior colleges). The team will also explore additional areas of expertise needed to address the this complex challenge (e.g., public health, public policy).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this project is to leverage the resources of a planning grant to develop and nurture relationships with the stakeholder community in a deliberate, early-stage process in an effort to develop a research team that is well poised to successfully compete for an Engineering Research Center addressing a highly complex, high-societal impact challenge. Inadequate and failing rural infrastructure is an important though arguably overlooked problem of national significance requiring center-scale, converging engineering research. The goal is to develop a convergent research team of multidisciplinary subject-matter experts to successfully reengineer the nation’s rural infrastructure including stakeholders from the target rural communities and the educational institutions that support them.  The Workshop on Innovations for Resilient Rural Communities was organized as a final step and it was originally planned for much earlier but the plans had to be changed due to COVID.  The event was held at Auburn University. 

To prepare a research team for a major NSF proposal on rural infrastructure it is important to establish working relationship with the stake holders, in particular representatives of resistances of rural communities in Alabama, Puerto Rico, Delaware, Colorado and California. The crucial parts of the project was organization of two workshops with stake holders (representatives of the rural communities).  The first workshop was held in summer 2022 and the second workshop in August 2023.  

The Workshop on Innovations for Resilient Rural Communities was organized as a final step in the NSF Planning Grant project. The objective was to present and discuss the problems related to rural communities to identify: (1) What are the problems that bother residents of rural communities?  What makes rural communities less attractive?  What are the differences in standard of living between rural and urban communities?  (2) What are available and emerging technologies that can be applied to upgrade standard of living in rural communities?  What are the limitations and barriers in application of these devices?  (3) Which of the available and emerging technologies, engineered system, can be considered as a theme for the development by a proposed NSF Engineering Research Center?  The participants were asked to prioritize concerns and innovation interests.  The results are presented in the attached bar-charts.  It was clear that reliable uninterrupted power and water supply with broadband communication are the top concern.  So addressing these problems is the most effective way to make rural communities more attractive.

In summary, Planning Grant helped to identify three themes as potential engineered systems that can be considered for NSF Engineering Research Center:

  • Rural Main Street - Creating a hub and revitalization of main street is an easy way to concentrate funding and effort
  • Rural Mobility – Improving mobility of services and people (including school buses, medical, supplies)
  • Rural Health Care - Improving health care system in rural communities (medical mini- units connected to centers)

In addition, interaction with representatives of partner institutions and stake-holders provided a basis for the selection of research team ready for to work on the next submission of NSF ERC proposal.
